content: The Act titled "Grow Our Own Directive: Physician Assistant Employment and Education Act of 2015" establishes a pilot program to provide educational assistance to physician assistants employed at the Department of Veterans Affairs. The "Grow Our Own Directive" pilot program provides educational assistance to former members of the Armed Forces to become physician assistants at the Department of Veterans Affairs. Eligible individuals must have medical or military health experience. The pilot program provides educational assistance to former Armed Forces members to become physician assistants at the Department of Veterans Affairs. Eligible individuals must have medical or military health experience, a degree in a health-related field, and experience in delivering health care services. They should not have a doctor of medicine degree. The pilot program offers educational assistance to former Armed Forces members to become physician assistants at the Department of Veterans Affairs. Eligible individuals must have medical or military health experience, a degree in a health-related field, and experience in delivering health care services. The program will run for five years, with the selection of at least 250 individuals prioritizing those with specific qualifications. The Secretary will select a minimum of 250 eligible individuals for the pilot program, giving priority to those who participated in a previous program or agree to work as a physician assistant at a designated medical facility. Between January 2011 and February 2015, individuals who agree to work as a physician assistant for the Veterans Health Administration at a medical facility in a designated medically underserved community with a high veteran population may receive educational assistance through a pilot program. The program aims to select a minimum of 250 eligible individuals, prioritizing those who have participated in a previous program or agree to work at a designated facility. The pilot program aims to provide educational assistance to individuals, including scholarships for obtaining a master's degree in physician assistant studies. The program targets a minimum of 250 eligible individuals who agree to work as physician assistants in medically underserved communities with a high veteran population. The Secretary will provide educational assistance through existing programs and scholarships for obtaining a master's degree in physician assistant studies. At least 35 scholarships will be offered each year under the pilot program. Participants will enter into an agreement for obligated service. The pilot program offers less than 35 scholarships each year to individuals who agree to work as physician assistants for the Veterans Health Administration for a specified period of obligated service. The pilot program offers scholarships for individuals to work as physician assistants for the Veterans Health Administration. The obligated service period can vary based on the program or be three years if not specified. Failure to fulfill the obligated service may result in liability. The pilot program offers scholarships for physician assistants to work for the Veterans Health Administration. Participants must fulfill a period of obligated service, typically three years. Failure to complete the service may result in liability to the United States. The pilot program provides scholarships for physician assistants to work for the Veterans Health Administration. Participants must complete a period of obligated service, with liability for failing to do so. Mentors are available for program participants, and partnerships are sought by the Secretary. The Secretary ensures physician assistant mentors are available for pilot program participants at Veterans Health Administration facilities. Partnerships are sought with accredited institutions offering master's degree programs in physician assistant studies for guaranteed seats in the program. Institutions offering programs in physician assistant studies accredited by the Accreditation Review Commission on Education for the Physician Assistant must guarantee seats for pilot program participants and provide information on admissions criteria. Other higher education institutions with similar programs are also eligible. The Secretary will administer the pilot program for physician assistant studies, appointing staff within the Office of Physician Assistant Services of the Veterans Health. Additionally, the program will be marketed to veterans and members of the Armed Forces through various channels. The Secretary will appoint a Deputy Director for Education and Career Development of Physician Assistants within the Office of Physician Assistant Services of the Veterans Health Administration to oversee the pilot program, recruit candidates, and coordinate with individuals. The Deputy Director for Education and Career Development of Physician Assistants oversees the pilot program, recruits candidates, coordinates with participants, and provides information to eligible individuals. They may also work at a medical center of the Department. The Deputy Director of Recruitment and Retention, a physician assistant and veteran, is responsible for coordinating the needs of the pilot program, providing mentors to participants, and managing facility staff. They may also work at a Department medical center. The Deputy Director of Recruitment and Retention, a physician assistant and veteran, is responsible for coordinating the needs of the pilot program, providing mentors to participants, managing facility staff, and working at a Department medical center. A recruiter reports to the Deputy Director and collaborates with Workforce Management. An administrative assistant at a minimum GS-6 level supports administrative tasks for the pilot program in the Office of Physician Assistant Services. The recruitment and retention of physician assistants within the Department is supported by an administrative assistant at a minimum GS-6 level. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will submit a report to Congress on the pilot program within one year of the Act's enactment, in collaboration with other relevant departments. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs, in collaboration with other departments, will submit a report to Congress on a pilot program for physician assistants, assessing its effectiveness in helping eligible individuals become physician assistants and achieve specific goals related to utilizing medical skills gained in the Armed Forces. The pilot program for physician assistants is being examined to determine if it is achieving its goals of enabling individuals to utilize medical skills gained in the Armed Forces and helping to address the shortage of physician assistants in the Department. The Secretaries of Veterans Affairs, Labor, Defense, and Health and Human Services will identify necessary modifications to meet these goals and assess the program's effectiveness. The pilot program for physician assistants will be assessed by the Secretaries of Veterans Affairs, Labor, Defense, and Health and Human Services to determine its effectiveness in helping individuals obtain certification and employment in healthcare fields. At least $8,000,000 of funding will come from the Department of Veterans Affairs for the program. Establishment of standards for the Department of Veterans Affairs to use educational assistance programs for training and hiring physician assistants. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will establish standards to improve the use of educational assistance programs for training and hiring physician assistants within the Department of Veterans Affairs. Directors of medical centers will be held accountable for utilizing these programs to advance employees' education and enhance recruitment and retention of physician assistants. The Department of Veterans Affairs will ensure the availability of the Education Debt Reduction Program for participants in the pilot program to fill vacant physician assistant positions. This includes including the program in vacancy announcements and informing applicants about it. The pilot program aims to fill vacant physician assistant positions at the Department by including the Education Debt Reduction Program in vacancy announcements and informing applicants of their eligibility. Compliance with educational assistance programs will be monitored, and new programs will be created, such as the Department of Veterans Affairs Employee Incentive Scholarship Program. The Secretary will create regulations to ensure educational assistance programs are fully utilized, including a program to encourage Department employees to apply to physician assistant programs. Establishment of pay grades for physician assistants of the Department of Veterans Affairs and requirement to provide competitive pay. The text discusses the establishment of pay grades for physician assistants in the Department of Veterans Affairs, including competitive pay and a national strategic plan for their retention and recruitment. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is required to implement a national strategic plan for the retention and recruitment of physician assistants, ensuring competitive pay compared to the private sector. A report on the plan's implementation must be submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs within one year of the Act's enactment.
